summary: This is a Department of Justice press release announcing the release of the executive summary of the Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) report on the 2006-2008 federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. The statement summarizes OPR's findings, which concluded that while no professional misconduct was found, victims were not treated properly and former U.S. Attorney Acosta exercised poor judgment in handling the case via a non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Release of OPR Report Executive Summary
events.description: The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility released the executive summary of its report investigating the handling of the Epstein case and victim interactions by the Southern District of Florida.

keyFacts: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) concluded that victims in the Epstein case were not treated with the 'forthrightness and sensitivity expected by the Department.'
OPR found that former U.S. Attorney Acosta 'exercised poor judgment' by resolving the federal investigation through a non-prosecution agreement (NPA).
OPR did not find that Department attorneys engaged in professional misconduct.
The full OPR report is protected by the Privacy Act but has been disclosed to a congressional committee with jurisdiction.
The report's findings will inform the DOJ's implementation of the Crime Victims' Rights Act and Attorney General's guidelines on victim assistance.
